user_request: A poem for a wedding about soulmates and happily ever after.
final_poem:
# Epilogue: The Long Haul

You said the word *soulmate* and I rolled my eyes,
the way I still roll them at your old habits—
the coffee, the radio station, your habit
of saying things like that with such plain conviction.

But here's the thing: I believe in it now.

Not as a story we tell at weddings,
not as the greeting-card version of love—that
steady beating heart before the vows—are you mine,
are you, are you?—but as something
more like weather. Not storm. Not sunny.
The kind of climate that has lasted so long
you forget it was ever up for choice.

I've watched you open tangerines wrong all your life;
I could finish your sentence before you said it.
These are not plotlines, these are bone structure—
how you hold your palm when you pray,
how patient you are with the kids in kindergarten,

how you look at me from the doorway
at two a.m. and don't need anything
except for me to know I'm wanted.

We didn't write our own happily ever after.
It was more like finding the mailbox
already full of letters we never addressed,
each one sealed with exactly the right stamp.

I used to think that meant someone else was choosing us.
Now I think it meant we were always already home,

just moving furniture, just adjusting
the thermostat, just learning
to say *later* instead of *never.*

So here's to the kind of love that doesn't declare itself—
the one that arrives wearing your old coat,
that knows the way to my kitchen without looking.

To us and whatever keeps coming next.
Not a story. A climate. And I'm in it
for however long it is.

The tangerine's still open wrong.
You're standing there with it, patient as ever,

and I don't mind at all because this is the sound
a house makes when it finally stops
trying to be somewhere else—this is us,
finally settled into whatever we were always meant to be,

which isn't euphemism. It's just Tuesday.
And we're here again. And you're peeling fruit.

Keep doing that. I'll finish your sentences.
We won't need them anymore.
